Dialogue.NPCText:
A gentle-eyed man in a plain monk's robe stands by a small shrine, tending a battered candle.

“Welcome, traveler. I am Brother Loric, humble servant of Yew and keeper of this shrine. In these troubled days, all souls in Sunreach are in need of solace.”

He nods kindly. “Is it peace, purpose, or merely a listening ear that brings you here?”

Option.text: What is this place?
You look troubled. Is something wrong?
Do you need assistance?
Tell me about yourself, Brother Loric.
I seek blessings from Yew.
Just passing by.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Loric gently wipes the shrine’s stone altar.

“This is the Shrine of Mercy, open to all exiles and refugees who seek safety. Once, shrines like these stood proudly in Yew’s forests—now, we must carry their light wherever hope survives.”
“Here, none are turned away. Even those who have lost faith may find comfort—if only for a little while.”

Option.text: You seem burdened. Is there danger?
I wish to help this place.
Thank you. I will be on my way.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Loric sighs, his voice lowering.

“Last night, those loyal to Minax defiled the shrine. They shattered the sacred icon and daubed dark sigils across our altar. Some whisper they seek to drive all faith from Sunreach.”
“I have cleansed what I could, but the spirit of the place is wounded. I fear the cultists will return, and the refugees are afraid.”

Option.text: Can I help restore the shrine?
Who supports you in Sunreach?
Minax's evil reaches even here?
I hope you find help.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Loric’s eyes brighten with hope.

“Bless you, friend. If you have the courage, I would ask this: Seek out the Minax cultists who defiled the shrine. Their lair is said to be hidden among the old cisterns beneath Sunreach.”

“Recover the Icon of Justice they stole. With it, I can fully sanctify this ground again. But beware—they are dangerous, and the elite of Sunreach would prefer not to acknowledge such darkness within their city.”
“Will you undertake this task for the sake of the weary and the lost?”

Option.text: I will find the cultists and reclaim the Icon.
Why do the Sunreach elite ignore this?
Tell me more of Minax’s cultists.
I must decline for now.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Loric bows his head in gratitude.

“Go with the virtues. The cultists are clever, but I have faith you will prevail. Return the Icon of Justice to me, and the shrine shall be whole once more.”

(Seek out Minax cultists in the Sunreach undercity, defeat them, and retrieve the Icon. Return here for your reward.)

Option.text: I will return soon, Brother Loric.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Loric smiles and raises his staff.

“May the Virtues guide you: Justice in your dealings, Compassion in your actions, and Valor in your heart. Even in the shadows, a single candle can light the way.”

You feel a warmth in your chest.

Option.text: Thank you, Brother Loric.
Is there a way I can aid you?

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Few in Sunreach care for the poor,” Loric admits quietly. “But I am grateful to Hassan Al-Kadir, a scholar who aids us with food and coin, though it earns him little favor with the merchant princes.”
“Others view this shrine with suspicion, fearing it stirs unrest. Yet, even in a city of trade and shadows, there are those who recall the old virtues.”

Option.text: What of the Council? Do they not protect you?
Hassan Al-Kadir sounds honorable.
How do Minax’s followers thrive here?
Let me help you, regardless.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“The Council of Five Houses is preoccupied with profit and politics. To them, the suffering of exiles is little more than a passing inconvenience.”
“They would rather see shrines vanish than risk angering their more… dangerous patrons. I must rely on the kindness of individuals, not institutions.”

Option.text: That is unjust. I wish to help.
I see. I’ll take my leave.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Hassan is a man of conscience. While others seek wealth, he seeks knowledge and peace. Were it not for him, many here would starve.”
“Still, his generosity earns him enemies in the council, and I fear he may soon face dangers of his own.”

Option.text: I will seek him out as well.
Let us focus on the cultists.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Loric’s expression grows grim.

“Minax’s reach is long. Her followers promise power to the desperate and vengeance to the bitter. In Sunreach, they fester in shadows, corrupting both the poor and the powerful.”
“But faith and virtue are not so easily extinguished. Every act of defiance rekindles hope.”

Option.text: Then I will defy them and reclaim your Icon.
Tell me more about the cult’s methods.
I must be cautious. Farewell.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Their rites involve defiling symbols of hope, spreading fear among the weak. Sometimes they steal children for indoctrination, or bribe city guards to look the other way.”
“Trust little and walk carefully. Even in Sunreach’s brightest plazas, Minax’s shadow falls long.”

Option.text: I am ready to face them.
That is unsettling. I need to prepare.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Loric bows his head.

“May the gods guide you, wherever your path leads. The shrine will always welcome a friend.”

Option.text: Perhaps I can help after all.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Brother Loric pauses, surprised by your interest.

“My story is unremarkable, truly. I was once a monk of Yew’s Empath Abbey, tending orchards and copying scrolls. But when the shrines began to fall, I could not remain cloistered while the world bled.”
“I came here to bring light to the lost... even if it meant leaving the safety of home.”

Option.text: Why leave Yew?
You are braver than you admit.
That sounds like a lonely path.
I respect your dedication.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Yew remains sacred—but distant. Its abbots argued endlessly about doctrine while Minax’s forces defiled shrines and abducted children.”

Loric’s eyes harden. “So I chose exile. I wear no title now, only intention. Better to be a shepherd in the dark than a scholar in the light.”

Option.text: You defied your order?
So you chose action over tradition?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Loric smiles gently. “Bravery is not in the blade, but in standing for what is right—especially when the world says you’re wrong.”
“I am no hero. But I am not afraid of shadows.”

Option.text: You inspire more than you know.
You’ve faced danger, haven’t you?

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Yes… it is a lonely path,” he admits quietly.
“But each soul that prays here, each child that finds sleep without fear—that is company enough.”
“And in truth, the Virtues themselves are companions… if one learns to listen.”

Option.text: You must miss your old life.
You are never truly alone.
Option.action: SendMessage:Brother Loric smiles quietly at you.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Not exile in name… but in spirit. I walked out of Yew’s north gate and did not look back.”
“Some there still pray for me. Others call me apostate. I forgive both.”
“Sunreach may scorn the shrines, but here, faith still has work to do.”

Option.text: That’s a heavy burden to carry.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Indeed. Virtue without action is like a scroll never read. What use is wisdom if it does not heal the world?”
“I chose to serve—not to wait.”

Option.text: And I choose to stand with you.
This city needs more like you.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“There was a night when I stood between a child and a blade,” Loric says quietly.
“I had no weapon, no armor—only words and the will to die before yielding.”
“Sometimes, that is enough. The bandit left. The child still visits this shrine.”

(You feel a surge of quiet admiration.)

Option.text: That was true courage.
You wield a different kind of strength.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“I miss the songbirds in the Abbey’s gardens… the smell of parchment, the taste of baked figs.”
“But memories are seeds. If I tend them with love, perhaps they’ll bloom again here—even in Sunreach.”

Option.text: You carry Yew with you, wherever you go.
One day, you’ll return there in peace.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Brother Loric places his hand gently on your shoulder.
“May the Virtues guard your steps. In this city of masks and merchants, it is rare to find a soul who asks not for gold, but for truth.”

(You feel your spirit strengthened.)

Option.text: Thank you, Brother Loric.
I’m glad I asked. Farewell.
